Article 102
An act that a person with qualified legal capacity performs as an agent of another person may not be rescinded on the grounds of qualified legal capacity;provided, however, that this does not apply to an act performed by a person with qualified legal capacity as a legal representative of another person with qualified legal capacity.
t2: A minor may not be an agent.
ChatGPT_output:
Thesis: The hypothesis being considered is "A minor may not be an agent."
 
Rule 1: The legal capacity of a person refers to the ability of an individual to enter into legally binding agreements or contracts. The legal capacity of a minor is limited because of their age, and as such, they may not be able to enter into certain types of contracts or agreements.

Rule 2: An agent is a person authorized to act on behalf of another person or entity in legal matters. The agent must have qualified legal capacity to perform legal acts on behalf of the principal.

Application: Based on the rules outlined above, it can be inferred that a minor may not be an agent since they lack qualified legal capacity. As a minor, they cannot enter into legally binding contracts, and therefore, they cannot act as an agent for another person.

Conclusion: Therefore, the hypothesis "A minor may not be an agent" is true based on the legal reasoning approach outlined above.

Article 608
(1) If a lessee has defrayed necessary expenses with respect to the leased thing which ought to be borne by the lessor, the lessee may immediately demand the reimbursement of the same from the lessor.
(2) If the lessee has incurred beneficial expenses with respect to the leased thing, the lessor must reimburse those expenses on termination of the lease in compliance with the provisions of Article 196, paragraph (2);provided, however, that the court may, at the lessor's request, grant a reasonable period of time for the reimbursement of the same.
t2: In cases where a lessee has defrayed necessary expenses with respect to the leased Thing in order to preserve the condition appropriate for profit from ordinary use of the subject, the lessee can wait for the end of the lease and demand the reimbursement of the same from the lessor.

Thesis: The hypothesis being considered is "In cases where a lessee has defrayed necessary expenses with respect to the leased Thing in order to preserve the condition appropriate for profit from ordinary use of the subject, the lessee can wait for the end of the lease and demand the reimbursement of the same from the lessor."

Rule 1: Article 608(1) states that if a lessee has defrayed necessary expenses with respect to the leased thing which ought to be borne by the lessor, the lessee may immediately demand the reimbursement of the same from the lessor. This means that if the expenses were necessary for the maintenance and preservation of the leased thing, the lessor must reimburse the lessee immediately.

Rule 2: Article 608(2) states that if the lessee has incurred beneficial expenses with respect to the leased thing, the lessor must reimburse those expenses on termination of the lease in compliance with the provisions of Article 196, paragraph (2). This means that if the expenses were for the improvement or enhancement of the leased thing and the lessee incurred them with the lessor's consent, the lessor must reimburse the lessee at the end of the lease.

Application: Based on the rules outlined above, it can be inferred that the hypothesis is true. If the lessee has defrayed necessary expenses with respect to the leased thing in order to preserve the condition appropriate for profit from ordinary use of the subject, they can wait for the end of the lease and demand the reimbursement of the same from the lessor. This is because necessary expenses are required for the maintenance and preservation of the leased thing, and the lessor is obligated to reimburse the lessee for such expenses. 

Conclusion: Therefore, the hypothesis "In cases where a lessee has defrayed necessary expenses with respect to the leased Thing in order to preserve the condition appropriate for profit from ordinary use of the subject, the lessee can wait for the end of the lease and demand the reimbursement of the same from the lessor" is true based on the legal reasoning approach outlined above.

Article 704
A beneficiary in bad faith must return the benefit received together with interest thereon. In such cases, if any damage still remains, the beneficiary is liable to compensate for this.
t2: The beneficiary in bad faith of unjust enrichment must return the benefit received together with interest, and if any damages still remain, the beneficiary shall be liable to compensate for the same.

Thesis: The hypothesis being considered is "The beneficiary in bad faith of unjust enrichment must return the benefit received together with interest, and if any damages still remain, the beneficiary shall be liable to compensate for the same."

Rule 1: Article 704 of the law states that a beneficiary in bad faith must return the benefit received together with interest thereon. This means that if a person has received a benefit to which they were not entitled, and they knew or should have known that they were not entitled to it, they must return the benefit and pay interest on the amount received.

Rule 2: The same Article 704 also states that in such cases, if any damage still remains, the beneficiary is liable to compensate for this. This means that if the beneficiary's bad faith caused any damages to the party from whom they received the benefit, they must compensate for these damages as well.

Application: Based on the rules outlined above, it can be inferred that the hypothesis is true. The beneficiary in bad faith of unjust enrichment must return the benefit received together with interest, as well as compensate for any damages caused by their bad faith. 

Conclusion: Therefore, the hypothesis "The beneficiary in bad faith of unjust enrichment must return the benefit received together with interest, and if any damages still remain, the beneficiary shall be liable to compensate for the same" is true based on the legal reasoning approach outlined above.

Article 715
(1) A person that employs another person for a business undertaking is liable to compensate for damage inflicted on a third party by that person's employees with respect to the execution of that business;provided, however, that this does not apply if the employer exercised reasonable care in appointing the employee or in supervising the business, or if the damage could not have been avoided even if the employer had exercised reasonable care.
(2) A person that supervises a business on behalf of the employer also has the liability referred to in the preceding paragraph.
(3) The provisions of the preceding two paragraphs do not preclude the employer or supervisor from exercising their right to reimbursement against the employee.
t2: The employer is released from his/her liability in cases when proof is provided that the employer made proper care regarding the appointment and supervision of the employee.
ChatGPT_output:
Thesis: The hypothesis being considered is "The employer is released from his/her liability in cases when proof is provided that the employer made proper care regarding the appointment and supervision of the employee."

Rule 1: Article 715(1) states that an employer is liable to compensate for damage inflicted on a third party by their employees with respect to the execution of the business. However, this liability does not apply if the employer exercised reasonable care in appointing the employee or in supervising the business, or if the damage could not have been avoided even if the employer had exercised reasonable care.

Rule 2: Article 715(2) states that a person who supervises a business on behalf of the employer also has the same liability as the employer with regard to compensation for damages inflicted on a third party by employees.

Application: Based on the rules outlined above, it can be inferred that the hypothesis is true. If the employer can prove that they exercised reasonable care in appointing and supervising the employee, they can be released from their liability for damages inflicted by their employees. However, if they failed to exercise reasonable care, they will still be held liable for any damages caused by their employees.

Conclusion: Therefore, the hypothesis "The employer is released from his/her liability in cases when proof is provided that the employer made proper care regarding the appointment and supervision of the employee" is true based on the legal reasoning approach outlined above.
